description: Alias collision stress test. Entities share overlapping aliases to test disambiguation.

notes.title: API Gateway
notes.content:
# API Gateway

The API Gateway handles all incoming requests for our microservices architecture. It integrates with our API Management platform for rate limiting and authentication.

notes.title: API Management
notes.content:
# API Management

API Management encompasses the processes of designing, publishing, documenting, and analyzing APIs. Our API Gateway uses APIM policies for throttling.

Spent the morning debugging the API Gateway deployment. David Chen helped identify the root cause in the api layer. The RAG pipeline is also having issues with retrieval latency. Need to check the ML Pipeline logs.

Afterward, reviewed the TypeScript migration plan. The TS config needs updating for the new test suite. React components are being refactored to use reactive patterns.

Met with James Franklin to discuss the ESGHub roadmap. The API Gateway team wants to integrate Retrieval Augmented Generation for smarter caching. David Chen raised concerns about the ML Pipeline resource usage.

Also explored Chen Province travel options for the team offsite. Docker containers for the staging environment need rebuilding.

Deep dive into Machine Learning model training. The RAG system needs better embeddings. Reviewed API Management policies with the platform team. Kubernetes cluster scaling issues in production.

Paired with David Chen on TypeScript type safety improvements. The test suite revealed several regressions in the reactive event handlers.

notes.title: API Architecture Review
notes.content:
# API Architecture Review

Attendees: David Chen, James Franklin

Discussed the relationship between API Management and API Gateway. The gateway handles routing while management handles lifecycle. Both share the api namespace which causes confusion.

Action: David Chen to document disambiguation guide. RAG integration timeline confirmed for Q2.

notes.title: ML Strategy Review
notes.content:
# ML Strategy Review

Attendees: James Franklin

Reviewed the Machine Learning roadmap. ML Pipeline throughput is 3x higher than last quarter. Discussed Retrieval Augmented Generation integration with ESGHub. The RAG system needs better retrieval from our Databricks warehouse.

TypeScript SDK for the ML models is ready for testing.

notes.title: Entity Disambiguation Guide
notes.content:
# Entity Disambiguation Guide

Common alias collisions in our codebase:

- api: Could mean API Management (concept) or API Gateway (project)
- RAG: Could mean Retrieval Augmented Generation or Databricks data tooling
- ML: Could mean Machine Learning (concept) or ML Pipeline (project)
- TS: Could mean TypeScript or Test Suite
- Chen: Could mean David Chen (person) or Chen Province (location)

Context is key for disambiguation. In code reviews, api usually means API Gateway. In architecture discussions, it means API Management.

notes.title: ESGHub
notes.content:
# ESGHub

Environmental Social Governance Hub. Built with React and TypeScript. Uses the API Gateway for external integrations. Kubernetes deployment managed by the platform team.

notes.title: David Chen
notes.content:
# David Chen

Senior architect at the company. Leads the API Gateway and API Management teams. Expert in Docker and Kubernetes deployments.

notes.title: James Franklin
notes.content:
# James Franklin

Engineering manager. Oversees ESGHub, ML Pipeline, and the Machine Learning research initiatives.

notes.title: Research Notes
notes.content:
Looking into Retrieval Augmented Generation patterns. The RAG approach uses embeddings to find relevant context before generating responses. Our Databricks cluster (DBR) could serve as the vector store.

Also reading about reactive programming patterns in React. The reactive event system pairs well with TypeScript for type-safe event handling.
